text: well joining us on the line now is
Mohammed Shafiq who is the chief
executive of the Ramadan foundation a
British Muslim community groups and he
joins us from Manchester in England
Mohammed thank you very much for joining
us what is your reaction to what has
happened in Paris today well as a human
being as a Muslim I totally condemned
this barbaric and evil crime if they
think that they have the right to kill
innocent people because they disagree
with cartoons then they're living in a
parallel universe
we as Muslims abhor the terrorism we
applaud their actions and they don't
stand they don't do it in my name or the
name of my grave faith I'm somebody who
opposes those cartoons I've consistently
opposed those cartoons but do that
through the political protests through
the media and through peaceful methods
there's no excuse for violence
whatsoever and in a democracy people are
free to express themselves how they want
to equally we are free to express our
opposition to those cartoons but no
violence is ever the solution to any
problem
are you surprised though by what
unfolded at the offices this morning I'm
not surprised because we're obviously
facing an heightened threat now from
Isis and other terrorist organizations
who think that the best way to damage
relations in our countries is to carry
out lone wolf attacks as we saw in
London last year Willie Rigby as we've
seen so brutally today in Paris
we as Muslims as Christians as Jews as
people of no faith only to come together
and unify against this threat the

we must not we must make sure that they

paper well I think if you want to

are all father I debate it's gonna be
based on tolerance it's gonna be based

cartoons that depict the Prophet

journalists are free to make those

and promote their issues in a free

there's no place for violence or

somehow violence is acceptable you know

there's a huge challenge now to expose
